units.title: Prepare HBSS/BSA/glucose with DNase
units.text:
1. Turn on rotating oven and allow it to heat up to 37 °C while you prepare your sample.
2. Obtain a 60 mm cell culture dish containing ~7 mL of HBSS/BSA/glucose.
3. Add 150 µL of pre-aliquoted DNase (10 mg/mL) to each dish.
units.rationale: These steps detail actionable preparation of the digestion buffer with critical reagent addition.

units.title: Dissect brain tissue in digestion buffer
units.text:
4. Obtain ~250 mg of human brain tissue per sample. Document case details.
▲ Caution Local institutional guidelines should always be followed when using human source materials since they can contain blood-borne pathogens. These protocols probably will include training, proper engineering and personal barrier protections.
5. Place in dish containing HBSS/BSA/glucose + DNase.
▲ Critical step It is crucial DNase is added to the solution at this step otherwise digestion will be inadequate. See also the troubleshooting advice for Steps 9 and 54.
6. With a scalpel, cut tissue into small (~2 mm × 2 mm chunks) in HBSS/BSA/glucose + DNase solution in a sterile environment (Fig. 2).
▲ Critical step Ideally, dissection should occur in a cell culture biosafety cabinet. If this is not possible, the tissue can be dissected outside of a hood with attention paid to best aseptic technique.
units.rationale: This sequence provides explicit, step-by-step instructions for tissue handling and dissection under critical conditions.

units.title: Distribute tissue and add collagenase/dispase
units.text:
7. Distribute tissue into three 15 mL conical tubes.
 • Aliquot the tissue–buffer solution in the dish into the tubes first
 • Use extra HBSS/BSA/glucose buffer to wash the dish and make up to 5 mL per tube
8. Add 167 µL of collagenase/dispase (100 mg/mL) to each tube. Please note, 167 µL of collagenase/dispase per 5 mL is equivalent to 33.4 µL of solution per 1 mL.
units.rationale: These steps specify precise volumes and procedures for enzymatic digestion setup.

units.title: Perform enzymatic digestion
units.text:
9. Digest for 30 min in rotating oven at 37 °C.
▲ Critical step Optimal enzymatic digestion is the most important factor to maximize yield. Therefore, this step may need optimizing to achieve sufficient but not too much digestion. See also the troubleshooting advice for Step 54.
units.rationale: This step defines the core incubation condition critical for cell yield, with explicit parameters.

units.title: Spin down digestion mixture
units.rationale: This is a discrete, actionable centrifugation step with defined parameters.

units.title: Prepare Percoll gradient tubes
units.text:
11. After samples have finished spinning, discard the supernatant by pouring out the liquid into a waste container.
▲ Critical step Do not aspirate the supernatant during the cell dissociation and digestion, as the cell pellet may be aspirated and lost.
12. Add 1 mL of HBSS/BSA/glucose and 50 µL of pre-aliquoted DNase (10 mg/mL) into each sample tube.
13. Gently mix/resuspend 50 times using a micropipette, taking care not to introduce bubbles, which may detrimentally affect the cells49.
14. Obtain two additional 15 mL conical tubes per each sample tube. For example, for three sample digestion tubes, obtain six tubes for Percoll filtration.
▲ Critical step Yield will be compromised if each digestion is not distributed into two Percoll tubes.
15. Dispense 4 mL of 22% Percoll into each new conical tube.
units.rationale: These steps outline the precise preparation and distribution of samples into Percoll gradient tubes with critical warnings.

units.title: Perform Percoll density gradient centrifugation
units.text:
16. Carefully dispense cell suspension from each sample tube into the new conical tubes containing 22% Percoll in equal amounts. Use ~750 µL per tube.
▲ Critical step The cell suspension should be dispensed on top of the Percoll.
17. Spin down for 10 min at 500g, 4 °C with no deceleration.
18. Discard supernatant.
19. Reunite contents of all Percoll tubes into one tube by resuspending the cell pellet in the HBSS/BSA/glucose remaining after pouring out the supernatant.
20. Spin down the sample tube for 5 min at 300g, 4 °C.
units.rationale: This sequence defines the core density gradient procedure with critical handling and centrifugation parameters.

units.title: Prepare master mix for immunostaining
units.text:
22. Add 200 µL of HBSS/BSA/glucose into a fresh tube.
23. Add 2 µL of each antibody and 1 µL of DAPI into the tube containing 200 µL of HBSS/BSA/glucose per sample.
Ab/Stain Dilution Volume
DAPI 1:200 1 μL
CD45 PE–Cy7 1:100 2 μL
CD146 PE 1:100 2 μL
ANPEP APC 1:100 2 μL
CD31 FITC 1:100 2 μL
units.rationale: This is a precise, quantitative protocol for preparing a standardized antibody master mix.

units.title: Immunostain cells
units.text:
24. After samples have finished spinning, discard supernatant.
25. Resuspend in ~200 µL of HBSS/BSA/glucose.
26. Add the master mix into the tube of resuspended cells.
27. Incubate for 15 min on ice. During this sample incubation, start preparing controls by following Steps 36–45.
28. Wash with 5 mL of HBSS/BSA/glucose and mix.
29. Spin down for 5 min at 300g, 4 °C.
30. Discard supernatant.
 • Note the amount of supernatant remaining in the tube; 500 µL of supernatant is needed to resuspend
 • Add additional HBSS/BSA/glucose if below the recommended 500 µL needed to resuspend
31. Resuspend cells.
units.rationale: This sequence details the immunostaining protocol with washing, incubation, and resuspension steps.

units.title: Filter and prepare cells for FACS
units.text:
32. Obtain one FACS tube and a 70 µm filter.
33. With the filter over the FACS tube, dispense the resuspended cells through the filter and into the FACS tube.
34. Seal the tube and place on ice.
▲ Critical step Cells should be analyzed as soon as possible. Longer periods of dissociation may compromise cell viability.
35. Take samples to FACS.
units.rationale: These steps specify the final preparation of cells for flow cytometry with critical handling instructions.
